primaryStatutes.title: Expungement of Criminal Records
primaryStatutes.description: Primary statute governing expungement eligibility and procedures in Tennessee

a1.description: Expungement for dismissed charges, acquittals, and certain completed diversions

eligibility: Class A, B, C misdemeanors that are not excluded

a1_B.description: Expungement for certain non-violent felony convictions

misdemeanor.description: One year from the date of conviction or completion of sentence, whichever is later
details: Count from final discharge of sentence
All fines and court costs must be paid

felony.description: Five years from the date of conviction or completion of sentence, whichever is later
details: Count from final discharge of sentence
All fines, restitution, and court costs must be paid

dismissed.description: Dismissed or acquitted charges may be expunged immediately
details: Must verify case is fully closed

diversion.description: Judicial or pretrial diversion may be expunged upon successful completion
details: No new criminal charges during diversion

felonies: Any sexual offense against a child
Any drug offense involving trafficking or manufacturing
misdemeanors: Criminal contempt in a domestic violence case

misdemeanors.description: Most non-violent misdemeanors are eligible after 1-year waiting period

felonies.description: Certain non-violent Class E felonies may be eligible after 5-year waiting period
examples: Simple possession of controlled substance (felony amount)

does: Removes the record from public view
Allows you to legally deny the arrest or conviction on most job applications
Removes record from most background checks
doesNot: Remove records from law enforcement databases
Prevent use in future sentencing if convicted again
Affect professional licensing board records in all cases

baseFee.description: Tennessee eliminated expungement fees for eligible petitions effective 2024
baseFee.note: Court clerks may still charge administrative processing fees

administrativeFees.description: Some counties charge small administrative processing fees

additionalForms: Affidavit of Indigency (if fee waiver requested)
Proof of payment of all court costs

steps.title: Verify Eligibility
steps.description: Confirm that your offense is eligible for expungement under Tennessee law
requirements: Confirm all court obligations are satisfied

steps.title: Obtain Criminal Records
steps.description: Get copies of your criminal records from the appropriate court
requirements: Contact the court clerk where convicted
Request certified copies of the judgment

steps.title: Complete Petition Forms
steps.description: Fill out the required expungement petition forms

steps.title: File with the Court
steps.description: Submit your petition to the court where you were convicted
requirements: File with the clerk of court

steps.title: Serve District Attorney
steps.description: Provide notice to the District Attorney's office
requirements: Deliver copy of petition to DA
Some counties may do this automatically

steps.title: Attend Hearing (if required)
steps.description: Some expungements require a court hearing
requirements: Many uncontested petitions are granted without hearing
